intro: Neotchihatchewia isatidea, commonly known as the desert dandelion, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble dandelions. The plant has basal leaves that are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, adapted to reduce water loss in harsh environments. It produces yellow flowers that bloom in the spring, followed by small, puffball-like seeds for wind dispersal. Neotchihatchewia isatidea is often found in sandy soils and is well-suited to thrive in low-water conditions.
